back.definition: Evaluate security posture de vendors antes de engagement. Questionnaires (SIG, CAIQ), certifications (SOC 2, ISO 27001), audits.
back.example: Target: Fazio Mechanical (HVAC vendor) no fue properly vetted. Small vendor = big risk. Assess ALL vendors con access.

back.definition: Security requirements in contracts. SLAs, breach notification (24-48h), audit rights, data handling, liability, insurance minimums.
back.example: Right to audit: Can inspect vendor security annually. Breach notification: Vendor must notify within 24h. Liability: Who pays if vendor causes breach?

back.definition: Don't assess once, forget. Continuous: Security ratings (BitSight, SecurityScorecard), news monitoring, re-assessment annually.
back.example: Vendor gets breached = your data at risk. Continuous monitoring alerts you. Can trigger re-assessment or termination.

back.definition: Your vendor's vendors. Supply chain depth. SolarWinds: Attackers compromised SolarWinds, SolarWinds' customers compromised.
back.example: Ask vendor: 'Who are YOUR critical vendors?'. Map supply chain. Understand dependencies. Fourth-party incidents happen.

unlock_content.title: Pre-Contract Assessment
points: Security questionnaire: SIG (Standardized Information Gathering), CAIQ (Consensus Assessments)
Certifications: SOC 2 Type II, ISO 27001, PCI DSS if handling cards
Penetration test reports: Request recent pentest results
Insurance: Cyber liability coverage $XM minimum
References: Talk to existing customers about vendor security
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Red flags: No certifications, refuses audit rights, no cyber insurance. Walk away.

unlock_content.title: Security Clauses
points: SLA: 99.9% uptime, MTTD <1 hour, MTTR <4 hours
Breach notification: 24-hour notification requirement
Audit rights: Annual security audit by your team or third party
Data handling: Where stored, encryption requirements, retention limits
Liability caps: What vendor pays if breach. Consider uncapped for gross negligence.
Termination: Can terminate immediately if material security breach
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Lawyers may push back on security clauses. Stand firm. Security is business risk.

unlock_content.title: Continuous Oversight
points: Annual re-assessment: Request updated SOC 2, questionnaire
Security ratings: BitSight, SecurityScorecard (external view)
News monitoring: Google alerts for vendor breaches
Quarterly business reviews: Include security in QBRs
Incident response coordination: Tabletop exercises with critical vendors
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Vendor gets breached = trigger contract breach clause. Re-assess or terminate.

unlock_content.title: Secure Termination
points: Data return/destruction: Certificate of destruction required
Access revocation: Disable all vendor accounts, VPN, systems
Remove from approved vendor list
Final audit: Verify data deleted, no backdoors left
Retain records: Keep assessment docs for compliance/legal
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Vendors become ex-employees too. Revoke access promptly when contract ends.

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Unrealistic. Modern business requires vendors. Need: manage risk, not avoid vendors.

options.text: Vendor assessment, network segmentation, monitoring, least privilege access
options.feedback: CORRECTO! Target defense: 1) Vendor assessment: Vet Fazio security. Questionnaire, audit. 2) Segmentation: Fazio VPN should access ONLY billing systems, NOT POS network. Zero Trust. 3) Monitoring: Alert on Fazio credentials accessing unusual systems (POS). 4) Least privilege: Fazio needs billing access, NOT network-wide. Multi-layered defense. One control fails, others catch.
Partially. SOC 2 es good indicator pero not sufficient. Small vendor como Fazio may not have SOC 2. Need layered approach.
